snippet: The conversion to electronic records has failed so far to reduce health care costs, according to a new study by the RAND Corporation, which issued a rosier report in 2005.
abstract: RAND Corporation report finds that conversion to electronic health records has failed so far to produce hoped-for savings in health care costs and has had mixed results in improving care and efficiency; findings contradict optimism of 2005 RAND study that was widely cited before shift began.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and JULIE CRESWELL

lead_paragraph: The conversion to electronic records has failed so far to reduce health care costs, according to a new study by the RAND Corporation, which issued a rosier report in 2005.

headline.seo: Electronic Records Systems Have Not Reduced Health Costs, Report Says
headline.main: In Second Look, Few Savings From Digital Health Records
headline.print_headline: In 2nd Look, Few Savings From Digital Care Records
